repnme.cdata!:
Malawi - Fiscal Management and Accelerating
            Growth Program

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Malawi Fiscal Management
            and Accelerating Growth Program were as follows: outcomes
            were highly satisfactory, sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was moderate, and the Bank
            performance and the Borrower performance were both highly
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: 1. Adjustment
            operations should not be complex for countries with weak
            implementation capacity; 2. Design of the adjustment
            operations need to be thoroughly worked out to avoid
            implementation delays; and 3. Expectations should be
            realistic in the case of transforming the state-run operations.

repnme.cdata!:
Malawi - Fiscal Management and Accelerating
            Growth Program (FIMAG) - Adjustment Credit - Release of the
            Second Tranche with Request for Waiver of One Condition

abstracts.cdata!:
This memorandum recommends the release
            of the second tranche of the Fiscal Adjustment and
            Accelerating Growth Program (FIMAG) Adjustment Credit
            (Credit No. 388 1 MAI). The memorandum argues that the
            Government of Malawi (Borrower or Government) has made
            overall satisfactory progress in implementing the program
            (the Program) supported by the Credit as set forth in its
            Letter of Development Policy (the LDP), and has met five of
            the six specific conditions for the release of the second
            tranche. Waiver for one condition relating to the reform of
            the Agricultural Development and Marketing Corporation
            (ADMARC) is being requested.

5325975.majtheme: Public sector governance,Environment and natural resource management,Rural development,Human development,Financial and private sector development

repnme.cdata!:
Malawi - Fiscal Management and Accelerating
            Growth Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Fiscal Management and Accelerating
            Growth Program Project for Malawi (FIMAG) will support
            structural reforms in: (i) Fiscal Management, (ii)
            Parastatal Reforms, (iii) Agriculture, and (iv) HIV/AIDS.
            The reforms in fiscal management are designed to strengthen
            the Government's capacity to meet macroeconomic
            stabilization targets while the parastatal reforms will help
            in both reducing the burden on the budget and improve
            delivery of key infrastructure services crucial for growth.
            The reforms in agriculture will contribute to growth by
            increasing the returns to smallholder farmers through
            creating better functioning land, tobacco and maize markets.
            The reforms in HIV/AIDS will provide the framework for
            channeling resources and strengthening institutions in order
            to mitigate the health and social impacts of HIVIAIDS. There
            are four main risks to the operation. First, there is a risk
            of policy slippage. Malawi goes to general elections in May
            2004. In the run up to the elections, there is a risk of
            fiscal slippages due to election related expenses. In
            addition, a new Government after May 2004 may be less
            committed to reforms than the present one. Second, there is
            a risk that delays in donor inflows could create the need to
            approach the domestic market tofinance the Budget. Third,
            there is risk of exogenous shocks, especially one of drought
            and famine, destabilizing the macroeconomic agenda. Fourth,
            there is risk arising from the high incidence of HIVIAIDS.
            The first risk has been mitigated by the wide consultations
            with all stakeholders, including civil society organizations
            (CSOs) to create broad support for the program and providing
            technical assistance to firm up the analytical basis for the
            reforms. The second risk has been mitigated by working
            closely with all our development partners, including the
            Common Approach to Budget Support (CABS) group and the
            African Development Bank (AfDB) to make sure that all our
            operations are coordinated. The third risk is mitigated by
            efforts made to strengthen the systems to respond quickly to
            early warnings of a possible famine. The fourth risk has
            been addressed by including HIV/AIDS as one of the four
            reform areas. The Credit consists of a single component of
            untied balance of payments support, which will be disbursed
            in two equal tranches.
